bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, October 17, 1940

div1.p: Moran writes that he is certain the shack on the Rojas farm is Camp Lazear Building No. 1, the infected-clothing building.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, October 17, 1940
div1.opener:
Havana, Oct. 17, 1940.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
MAYO CLINIC,
ROCHESTER, Minn.
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
I repeat that, “Beyond peradventure of a doubt”, we have Bld'g
No. 1. If you own a pipe, put that in it and smoke it. This afternoon
I checked up on the matter of distance between the two buildings, using
the small tree at the right of me in my photo No. 21 as a guide. The
distance is 246 feet. It is more than likely that Major Reed or one of
his subordinates stepped it off. The Agramonte drawing does not worry
me in the slightest since I am morally convinced that he did not visit the
two buildings at the time and that the drawings were made from memory, the
particulars being dictated or roughly outlined to a draftsman by Dr. Agra-
monte. Please get out your photo (Army) 16-a. It gives you an end view
of Building No. 1 and if the stovepipe or chimney had existed at the right,
it would show up in that picture. Being in the left corner of the room,
it is not visible. You can see the vestibule in the photo and you know
that the vestibule was in front, facing Building No. 2. There was nothing
in the back of the shack. If you are not convinced, I GIVE IT UP. The
buildings were put up by Army carpenters, I am sure, and one or two inches
more or less in a building intended for a given purpose and for a period
of months only, was nothing in their young lives.

I went out to the site this afternoon before I received copy
of your letter to Pogolotti, intending to kill two birds with one stone,
viz: take Z's declaration, short and to the point, and at the same time
measure the distance between the two shacks. I just talked to Pogolotti
over the telephone. Your letter has not reached him yet but it should
be delivered to him tomorrow morning. I told him about the measurements
and they more or less agreed with what he estimated a few days ago when
I mentioned the matter to him. Just a matter of converting meters into
yards or direct into feet. He is not familiar with yards, feet and in-
ches, used very little in this country and in the country of his birth.
The square limeslaker you see in photo 16-a and the limekilns near it, which
are not visible in the picture, were torn down when the quarry and kilns
were moved further. towards the base of supply of limestone, having kept on
moving to where you saw them while you were here.

I have to type Z's statements, translate them to him in Spanish
and get his signature to them in English or American. Maybe I can get them
off to you with this letter and the nine photostats, one of which has no
bearing on the Camp since it concerns receipt of the amount due when the
the “2nd Regiment of South Carolina” occupied part of the farm from January
1st to May 15th, 1899, payment NOT HAVING BEEN MADE until March 11, 1901,
due, no doubt, to “red tape” in getting the vouchers properly certified
by the Commanding Officer of the Regiment who had returned to the U. S. and
had been mustered out. The entry commences “Collected, at last,”, etc.
The white squares in the photostats are to indicate the entries concerned.
(The 2nd Regiment of South Carolina" page is 94.)
div1.closer:
Sincerely, John J. Moran Leaving Havana on the Sunday (7:00 P. M.) steamer,
October 20th. My R. R. ticket is to Pittsburgh,
Va. and Philadelphia to be covered otherwise.
N. B. I think I have spelt Z's name wrong in several letters.
As I first wrote to you, it is Zunzunegui (pronounced
Zoon-zoon-eggy). In recent letters I have written it
Zunzunequi, which is wrong. Sorry. J. J. M.
